http://www.ft.com/...hill-takeover-bid/

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 324.40, down 3 (-0.92%), High: 327.60, Low: 319.00, Volume: 1.70m
11:10 am
BE

A gaming consortium formed by Rank Group and 888 have submitted a takeover offer for their larger rival William Hill that potentially values the UK bookmaker at up to £3.6bn, reports Bryce Elder, Paul McClean and Arash Massoudi.

The Rank and 888 consortium is said to have submitted a formal offer for William Hill that values the shares at 364p apiece as well as setting out merger synergies that boost the value of the proposal to 408p a share, according to two people briefed on the plans. William Hill shares were trading at 324.9p in early trading on Tuesday, down 0.8 per cent.

A tie-up between 888, Rank and William Hill would create a company with revenues of £2.7bn and earnings of £500m, making it the third-largest online betting company by revenues.

Spokespersons for William Hill, 888 and Rank declined to comment.

Online bookie 888 confirmed last month that as part of a consortium with Rank Group, the owner of Grosvenor Casinos and Mecca Bingo, it was weighing up an offer for William Hill. The deal would mark a stark turn of events, after William Hill tried and failed to acquire 888 in a £700m deal last year.

The approach from 888 and Rank is driven by a desire to gain greater scale to help absorb the costs from tougher regulation and higher taxes. For William Hill, a merger with the two groups would give it much-needed access to 888’s online platforms and technological capabilities.

The merger would also boost its geographical diversity — 85 per cent of William Hill’s £1.5bn revenues are generated in the UK, while 888 is far less focused on the British market, with 54 per cent of its $462m revenues coming from outside the UK.

11:18 am
BE

Goodbody .....

BE

We believe that there could be significant cost synergies from combining the three businesses. Looking at the breakdown of costs within the combined entity, we estimate there is c.£75m of central costs across the three operators. There is unlikely to be a significant amount (although there will be some) of cost synergies from combining Rank’s and William Hill’s retail estates. Therefore, just looking at the online cost bases across the three operators, there is a combined £726m of online costs. We can omit taxes/duties from this analysis and assuming the brands are not consolidated, we can also exclude marketing costs. This leaves £346m of overlapping online costs which, when combined with central costs, leaves £421m of total overlapping costs. We believe it would be reasonable to assume 25% of these could be realised as cost synergies, which implies total synergies of £105m and post synergies EBITDA of £637m. While some people may view 25% as an aggressive assumption we get comfort due to a number of factors. The online operation of the combined group would be of significant scale, at £1bn of revenue, and uses its own proprietary technology, suggesting decent cost synergy potential. In addition, as we noted above we do not assume any retail or marketing synergies, where infact there is likely to be some synergies in these areas.

BE

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?

A: H1 results better than expected with EBITDA 6%/5% above UBSe/Cons.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?

A: Key focus areas: 1) Both Global eCom and WPUK were better than expected with
WPUS in-line. 2) Company does not expect UK referendum result will have a material
effect on trading but has increased uncertainty. 3) No material effect is expected from
the recent payment gateway outage. 4) Incremental capex guide of £30m in 16/17. 5)
Company has announced its first interim dividend of 0.65p, above UBSe of 0.55p.

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?

A: Following better than target growth in H1, management is guiding to a return to its
target range in H2 (9-11% in H2 in-line with cons). Given H1 beat and currency
tailwind in H2, we would expect consensus to rise by at least 2% for FY16 EBITDA.

Q: How would we expect investors to react?

A: The shares have performed well recently but strong results and a solid guide we
believe should provide investors with further confidence in the business.

11:31 am
BE

And Goldman. Which floated it, right?

PM

think so

BE

n our view, Worldpay's analyst conference call was positive in tone and focused on strong business fundamentals. Our key takeaways from the 1HFY16 conference call:

· Strong 1H performance (+14%yoy ex-FX) was broad based with solid growth across the three segments (UK, US, Global eCom) driven primarily by underlying volume growth, new customer adds and strong retention rates (stable to marginally improving churn rates). Worldpay also benefitted from some one-off positives including new contract renewals in 1H and believe that 2H organic revenue growth will be more normal and within the 9-11% guidance range.
· Improvement in UK take rates was driven by more value added services and also benefitted from change in EU interchange regulations. Going forward, management expects UK take rates to be stable near term and any increase in pricing will be driven by higher adoption of value added services and new customer additions.
· eCom pipeline remains strong and Worldpay stated that it has extended multi-year contracts with two large tech customers with better pricing dynamics. Worldpay believes it has strong capabilities and licenses across global markets which should drive higher volumes across existing and new customers.
· With respect to the turnaround plan in US, management indicated that it is on track, with a large part of investments in various initiatives done, including ongoing investments in new product proposition as well integration of Securenet into the integrated platform. Decrease in US take rates is primarily driven by increase in corporate customers in the mix where spreads are lower than SMEs.
· Capex spending in the near term was ticked up by an incremental £15mn in 2016 and 2017 as Worldpay brings forward some investments. However, Management noted that that capex will come down to the normalized levels of 9-10% of net revenues by 2H17.
· Worldpay stated that its new technology platform transition was broadly on track and it has begun onboarding customers to the new platform with the process expected to complete in one year.

11:32 am
BE

We rate Worldpay Buy as we expect it to outperform given its attractive combination of defensive attributes (c.90% recurring revenues) and exposure to structural growth pockets. We believe WP’s tech platform, that encompasses offline/online merchant processing together with value-added services, positions it well to benefit from structural growth in the attractive and rapidly changing payments arena. Our 12-month price target is 350p, based on our core valuation of 335p/share (15.5x 2017E EV/EBITDA) at an 85% weighting, with a 15% weighting to our M&A valuation of 435p/share (19.5x 2017E EV/EBITDA). Key risks: Technology platform transition; competitor action – from new disruptors and incumbents; acquisition integration; changes in regulation and disintermediation; being with the right distribution agents (in the US) and pricing pressure.

BE

EZJ’s low cost business model is resilient and it has generated strong profits and taken significant market share in previous difficult macro environments. The stock is down 40% YTD due to concerns about trading, disruption to operations and Brexit. But we think that these concerns are overdone and the stock is oversold. We believe that travel spend across Europe will be more resilient than some investors fear. Moreover, EZJ can use its financial strength to discount aggressively and build share. Our conservative forecasts build-in a weaker pricing scenario. The stock is trading at a 24% discount to its five-year average PE. We upgrade to BUY from HOLD, TP lifted to £13 from £12.

BE

Anyway, Ocado confirms shares 30% of Erith

11:49 am
BE

There's nothing much in terms of detail.

BE

Andrew Wade at Numis is a buyer, and always worth reading.

BE

The deal is structured largely as a template OSP-style deal, with Morrisons to pay
an undisclosed annual capacity-based fee (partly offset versus the annual R&D fee
already paid), but incur much more limited up-front capex requirements; Morrisons will
meet 30% of build costs (but nothing for MHE) in addition to its ongoing share of fixed
costs. Unusually for an OSP deal, and reflecting the fact that Ocado will be operating
the site (like Dordon/CFC2), Morrisons will foot its share of all variable costs, certain
of which will attract a 4% management fee. The term of the Erith agreement will be 30
years, with Morrisons allowed to break from five years. In addition, Ocado will license
its OSP store-pick module to Morrisons, who will pay an up-front access fee and an
annual license fee (% of sales); the roll-out of store-pick is expected in 2017.

11:50 am
BE

Two other, separate, changes to the original agreement have also been made. The first,
sees Ocado waive its right to additional fees when Morrisons.com becomes profitable
(was up to 25% of profit), in return for a reduction in the exclusivity restrictions, such that
it may provide services to certain UK grocery retailers. The second, is an expansion
to include certain general merchandise products, where Ocado will act as a sourcing
agent for Morrisons, presumably earning a fee while building purchasing strength.

BE

In aggregate, these factors are likely to have little impact on FY16 and FY17 estimates,
as 1) Erith will not commence operations until FY18, 2) store-pick will not commence
operation until later in FY17 and, like general merchandise, is likely to be initially
relatively small and result in offsetting incremental costs, and 3) the capex saving
on Erith will require to be invested in developing further future capacity for Ocado.
Nevertheless, Ocado does comment that, presumably in later years, it expects these
agreements to be earnings accretive – this makes sense, given the additional fees
set against the incremental nature of the additional costs. Essentially, the shift to an
OSP-style agreement transfers the return-on-capex risk-reward to Ocado, and the key
indicators become ROI-based, rather than simply earnings accretion.

undefined

BE

Here's Barclays to summarise.

11:56 am
BE

While 1H16 trading profit was in-line with our above consensus estimates, the
outlook was just a little bit weaker than we had expected. 2H16 revenues should fall
by 10% y/y, despite a strong 1H16 and whilst the previous FY outlook for margins
falling “significantly” less than 100bp still directionally holds, the magnitude, in our
opinion does not. As such we are cutting our 2016F trading profit expectations by
(8)% and go-forward estimates by (5)-(9)%. However, consensus was on the
cautious side and largely already there. On a positive note, cost savings are being
delivered and an extra GB£200mn of disposals have been identified, albeit with the
existing proposed disposals, likely to attain less. Net debt crept up to GB£1.1bn and
is set to remain there all year. The key now for AmecFW, is elaborating the company
vision and deleveraging. A fall in trading profit of (13)% y/y is relatively resilient in
the Oil Services sector, highlighting the diversified nature of the company, with
Clean Energy especially strong. This diversified nature should be a cornerstone of
the new CEO’s strategy to be articulated in November, ahead of which a further
GB£440mn of assets have been written down. The early message is, in our view, one
of a reactive CEO who makes decisive changes. However, investors may take a wait-
and-see approach to these results, With the stock yielding ca5%, a potential
modified strategy imminent, the Americas partly repaired, and disposals to come,
we feel that near-term momentum is supportive. Hence, with nearly 30% potential
upside to our reduced GB600p/share price target, we remain Overweight.

BE

Americas upset the delivery: 1H16 saw strong delivery, but was marred by the
Americas where a 50% fall in Oil & Gas revenues came as a marked surprise to us and
judging by the 4.6% margin recorded in the region, also the company. AmecFW has
already made “significant remedial action” in the region, including “senior management
changes”, a quick and decisive move by the new CEO.
When is “significant” significant: With 1H16 revenues some 10% above consensus,
trading profit margins came in lower at 6.2%. Guidance for 2H16’s margins is similar,
implying to us an 80bp fall y/y for 2016F versus previous guidance for “significantly
less than 100bp”. While, the Americas disappointment makes up a large part of the
shortfall, it still suggests to us a weaker than previously expected go-forward rate.

BE

And SocGen .....

11:57 am
BE

Our first thoughts on Amec FW’s 1H results are positive. In addition to the
headline figures, we note the following positive steps taken by AMFW: 1) Cost reductions,
with headcount having at last been reduced c.10% to 36,000; and 2) AMFW is now well
advanced on its own in energy transition thanks to the US solarium win. We also note that
the new CEO comes across as less ‘promotional’ than his predecessors, who would likely
have led on the ‘beat’.

Profit warning to the upside

12:00 pm
PM

Consequently, the board now anticipates that the results for the current year will be above expectations with increased sales growth of between 28% and 33% (against previous guidance of 25% to 30%). As a result of operating leverage in the business, the board currently anticipates improved EBITDA margins for the financial year and further guidance will be given at the interim results in September. The board continues to be positive about the trading environment for boohoo.com.

PM

Here's some Shore

PM

Positive momentum continues for fast-fashion online retailer Boohoo, which today (9th August 2016) provided a
surprise update on current trading in the business. The performance of the company during the first five months of
the financial year has been sufficiently strong enough for management to upgrade guidance for both revenue and
EBITDA.
Summer sales strong
Boohoo now expects to deliver FY2017 sales ahead of current market expectations, with management now guiding to a
sales growth range of between 28% and 33% (prior guidance range: between 25% and 30%). Following today’s statement
and a call with management, we have sufficient confidence to upgrade our expectations for the current financial year. We
have bumped up our revenue estimate for FY2017 from £251.5m (growth rate: 28.7%) to £257.1m (31.6%)

12:01 pm
BE

It's turned into an interesting business. Own-brand, rather cheap, with marketing that seems to hit the Century 21, Urban Outfitters kind-of demographic better than its rivals.

PM

hmm

PM

Rest of Shore..

12:01 pm
BE

No idea what it should be worth, mind. Not a clue.

PM

Strong at home and overseas
During Q2, sell-through of stock has been strong and we believe sales growth continues to be healthy across all
three segments; UK, Europe and Rest of the World. Amongst this, performance has been robust in all of Boohoo’s
key markets, where it has been able to leverage marketing investment more effectively through the Spring/Summer
season. We anticipate that the company may reinvest some of the incremental earnings (from the first half) in the
proposition to continue to maintain top-line strength in the second half.
Price, product and delivery are key proposition drivers
Domestically, Boohoo continues to reap the benefit of delivery promotions, whilst price promotions are less seasonal
and lumpy, helping to support margin consistency. Further afield, the company is more content with the base prices
set overseas, although the frequency of price promotions has been increased in foreign markets. Whilst the company
does not anticipate using currency as a core driver of sales growth following the recent post UK/EU Referndum
devaluation of sterling, currency movements do present an opportunity to ramp up such promotional activity to drive
incremental sales. Boohoo has also seen a continuation of higher average order values from Q1 FY2017, with
investment in the mobile proposition helping to provide uplift in conversion rates.
Margin expansion
At the start of the year, management guided towards a flat EBITDA margin (9.6%), but with the business having
achieved improved operating leverage, we now expect a stronger EBITDA margin for FY2017. We now expect a
margin expansion of c70bps during FY2017. Having upgraded our FY2017 adjusted EBITDA forecast to £26.6m, this
represents an increase of c11% in profit from our prior forecast.

PM

Here's their valuation work

12:02 pm
PM

Whilst traditionally we always look at earnings multiples such as PER and EV/EBITDA, EV/sales is now a core
component of our valuation analysis for pure-play online growth businesses. Boohoo currently trades on a FY2017F
PER of 48.8x and a FY2017F EV/EBITDA ratio of 31.9x. We believe this premium to the online peer group sector
average is reflective of the fact that Boohoo is a more immature company, and is at an earlier stage of the business
lifecycle. We derive an intrinsic value of the stock of 92p, based on our revised forecasts; this would place the
company’s shares on 3.0x FY2018F sales.
We believe there is further upside on this valuation when we factor in the option to buy PrettyLittleThing, which we
previously valued at 4p per share (based on an EV/historic sales multiple) to shareholders. Whilst we do not have
great visibility on current trading in that particular business, we believe its growth rate remains above the core
Boohoo business, with a recent successful launch in the US last month.
Investors can be enthused that Boohoo has demonstrated an ability to accelerate both revenue and earnings
simultaneously during the period as well as about the cash-generative business model as a whole. We continue to
be bullish about the company’s future prospects and we retain a BUY stance on the company.

PM
